de.esoco.lib.logging

Class Log

  • java.lang.Object
    • de.esoco.lib.logging.Log

  • public final class Log
extends java.lang.Object
    Main class of a logging framework that is as simple to use as possible. No static log instance is necessary, only the invocation of a static method like Log.warn(String). Log levels can be enabled or disabled globally, independent of the underlying logging system. This can be done either for single log levels with setGlobalLogLevels(LogLevel[]) or for a range of levels with setGlobalMinimumLogLevel(LogLevel) (ordered by level severity).

    There is also a set of log methods that accept a format string and a list of format arguments (like warnf(Throwable, String, Object...)). These method also have the advantage that the message formatting only takes place on actual output. If the formatting of message objects is expensive these methods should be used to prevent unnecessary string conversions.

    The logging can be controlled by several system properties which can be set on the command line of a VM with the '-D' switch. The supported logging properties are:

    • esoco.log.file=[filename]: the name and path of the log file (default logging is on the console)
    • esoco.log.level=[LogLevel]: the global minimum log level
    • esoco.log.plevels=[list of package log levels]: allows to constrain the minimum log level for certain packages or classes. The package level must be higher than the global level or else this property will be ignored. The property must be set to at least one entry of the form [package/class name]=[LogLevel], multiple entries must be separated by commas. If a package name is given the given log level applies to all classes in the package and it's sub-packages.

      • addLogAspect

        public static void addLogAspect(LogAspect<?> rLogAspect)
        Adds a certain log aspect. The log aspect will be registered and initialized to start logging. If a log aspect with the same class already exists it will be shut down and removed first.
        Parameters:
        rLogAspect - The log aspect to register

        Returns:

      • registerLogHandler

        public static void registerLogHandler(java.lang.Class<?> rClass,
                                      java.util.function.Consumer<? super LogRecord> rNewHandler)
        Registers a log handler to be used for the logging of events from a certain class. All logging calls from that class will be logged through that handler.
        Parameters:
        rClass - The root package to register the handler for
        rNewHandler - The log handler to register or NULL to remove the log handler for the given class

      • registerLogHandler

        public static void registerLogHandler(java.lang.Package rPackage,
                                      java.util.function.Consumer<? super LogRecord> rNewHandler)
        Registers a log handler to be used for the logging of events from a certain package. All logging calls from classes in and below that package will be logged through that handler.
        Parameters:
        rPackage - The root package to register the handler for
        rNewHandler - The log handler to register or NULL to remove the log handler for the given package

      • removeDefaultLogHandler

        public static void removeDefaultLogHandler(java.util.function.Consumer<? super LogRecord> rHandler)
        Removes a log handler from the default log handlers.
        Parameters:
        rHandler - The default log handler to remove

      • removeLogAspect

        public static void removeLogAspect(java.lang.Class<? extends LogAspect<?>> rLogAspectType)
        Removes a log aspect with a certain type. The log aspect will be shut down and then removed from the log aspect registry. If no log aspect with the given type has been registered the call will be ignored.
        Parameters:
        rLogAspectType - The class of the log aspect to remove

      • removeStandardLogHandler

        public static void removeStandardLogHandler()
        Removes the standard log handler (@see getStandardLogHandler()).

      • setGlobalLogLevels

        public static void setGlobalLogLevels(LogLevel... rLevels)
        Enables certain global log levels. Independent of the log handler for a certain class only messages with one of these levels will be logged, all other levels will be disabled. The ordering of log levels is ignored by this method. If no log levels are provided (i.e. the argument list is empty) all levels except FATAL will be disabled. The log level FATAL cannot be disabled globally.
        Parameters:
        rLevels - The minimum level to log

      • setGlobalMinimumLogLevel

        public static void setGlobalMinimumLogLevel(LogLevel rLevel)
        Sets the minimum global log level (= severity). Independent of the log handler for a certain class only messages with this level or greater will be logged. The order of log levels from lower to higher severity is TRACE, DEBUG, INFO, WARN, ERROR, FATAL. The log level FATAL cannot be disabled globally.
        Parameters:
        rLevel - The minimum level to log

      • setLogLevel

        public static void setLogLevel(java.lang.String sPackageOrClass,
                               LogLevel eLevel)
        Sets the minimum log level for a certain class or package. This will only have an effect if the global log level is lower than the given package level. This allows to reduce the log output for certain classes or (parent) packages.
        Parameters:
        sPackageOrClass - The name of the class or package to set the log level for
        eLevel - The minimum log level for the given package or NULL to remove any special log handling for the given name
